Braves: For our final #MusicMonday, please see the following message from Jeff Clark:

Victor Hugo said “music expresses that which cannot be said and on which it is impossible to be silent.” When discovering Grace Coberly’s recent composition, I was struck not only in the beauty of the text and melody, but in the lyricism and how it fit our own “haven in the woods.” Though originally planned for our Spring concert, this piece truly encapsulated the essence of the Indian Hill High School choir program during the ongoing pandemic. Dedicated to the Class of 2020, please enjoy our virtual choir performance of Homeland.

You can follow Indian Hill Choirs on Twitter! @IHHSChoirs

https://youtu.be/tcFva_eVJEw

Important signs your student needs you

As I began writing this week’s edition of #BRAVEMinds, I was shocked to see that this is already the fifth week for this series. Some days it feels like a lifetime since our definition of normal changed so abruptly, and other days it feels like it was just yesterday. At any rate, it is difficult sometimes to envision when we will be able to return to normal.

For children and teens this uncertainty can evoke a range of emotions and feelings. As a parent, it may be difficult to determine what is a normal response and what is cause for seeking professional help.

This series, authored by Director of Pupil Services Erica Leppert, is intended to provide you important information about brain health. Up first: COVID-19 & Parenting:

As we begin the second week of distance learning, our lives look much different than they did a few short weeks ago. Busy family schedules have been replaced with managing work, school, and everyday life all within the walls of our homes. Some of us have had to cancel vacations, weddings, other major life events, and maybe there are more cancellations to come. The words we’ve heard over and over in the past few weeks, “unprecedented,” “uncertain,” “uncharted,” do little to offer any comfort. We’ve probably all experienced a heightened level of stress since school has been closed.

Know this: You are not alone!

Click the link to read more and access important resources:

March 3 at 7:21 PM ·

Hi IH Families,
Brave-A-Thon is about Time Travel.

No we don’t have those cool Time Turners from Harry Potter, but we do have PIONEER DAYS!! And they are upon us!

The ES 4th graders travel back in time to do things the pioneer way. Cook stew on an open fire, make baskets from reeds, dip candles, make corn husk dolls, learn about pioneer music, and much much more. They even dress up.
I think one of the sweetest parts is watching them all sit and share a meal together that they all played a role in making with the candles they dipped on the tables!

Kelly Blessing Hayden and Jeffrey Heinichen did an excellent job planning this year. Lots of parents were onsite to help set up like Melissa Lynn…

The Indian Hill School District in partnership with the Indian Hill PTO invites all parents to attend A Wired Family, a special presentation on technology and student health, 7 p.m. Tuesday, March 17, in the Indian Hill High School Auditorium. This powerful program has been presented to over 500,000 students and adults. It covers the basics concerning the evolution of the mobile and broadband world as it relates to student communication, including: inappropriate online behavior, and bullying and its impact on mental health. The presentation, delivered by A Wired Family President Stephen Smith, will cover the causes, the technology, and how students can help control these trends.

Please note: This presentation has been designed for adults only.
